topic: Deep dive: _frozen_importlib standard library module in Python 3.12+
prompt: Write a Python 3.12+ focused, accurate explainer for: Deep dive: _frozen_importlib standard library module in Python 3.12+

response_parsed.title: Deep Dive: frozenset() and frozendict() functions in Python 3.12+
response_parsed.summary: This explainer provides an in-depth analysis of the _frozen_importlib standard library module introduced in Python 3.12, focusing on the new frozenset() and frozendict() functions.
key_points: The _frozen_importlib module is a part of the Python Standard Library and offers functionality related to importing modules and packages.
_frozen_importlib was introduced in Python 3.12 and now includes frozenset() and frozendict() functions.
frozenset() creates an immutable set from any iterable, providing a constant memory footprint.
frozendict() creates an immutable dictionary with the same functionality as frozenset().
Both functions are useful for creating read-only containers in Python 3.12.

code_examples.code:
import _frozen_importlib as frozenset

frozen_set = frozenset([1, 2, 3])
print(frozen_set)

from _frozen_importlib import frozendict

dictionary = {'a': 1, 'b': 2}
frozen_dict = frozendict(dictionary)
print(frozen_dict)

version_notes: The _frozen_importlib module and its functions are exclusive to Python 3.12 or later.
Python versions prior to 3.12 do not have access to frozenset() and frozendict().
caveats: Although frozenset() and frozendict() are useful for creating immutable containers, they do not provide any significant performance improvement over traditional sets or dictionaries in most use-cases.
The _frozen_importlib module is intended to be used for importing modules and packages, but the new functions can also create read-only containers.
